title: FTSE 100 movers: Miners lead market loer on China data
text:
2.1863 0.0000 
LONDON (ShareCast) - (ShareCast News) - The FTSE 100 was slightly lower on Monday, led by miners on the back of disappointing export data from China. The index was down 30 points or 0.45% to 6688.23%. 
Chinese exports fell 8.3%, the biggest drop in four months and more than forecasts for a 1% decline. Imports dipped 8.1% in July, in line with market consensus. 
Separately, Chinese inflation grew 1.6% year-on-year in July, up from 1.4% the previous month and ahead of estimates of 1.5%. However, the figure remains well below the government's target of around 3%, adding pressure to roll out more stimulus to support China's economy. 
In London, shares in heavyweight insurer Prudential (HKSE: 2378.HK - news ) were down almost 2% ahead of half-year results on Tuesday. The company is waiting for details on a change in US law that could stifle sales of variable annuities. 
Miners Anglo American and BHP Biliton fell 2% and 1.72% respectively, as the sector continued to be depressed by the poor numbers from China falling metals prices. 
Supermarket stock were also in the red with Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) and Sainsbury (Amsterdam: SJ6.AS - news ) 's both down around 2%. 
On the positive side, shares in satellite telecoms group Inmarsat (Other OTC: IMASF - news ) continued to rise on news that the launch of its third Global Xpress satellite has been rescheduled for this month. 
Shire (Xetra: S7E.DE - news ) rose 0.85% on news that it is poised to start formal takeover talks with US rival Baxalta (Berlin: 9BX.BE - news ) in a deal that could be worth Â£20bn. 
London Stock Exchange Group rose 0.62% after excellent first-half profits numbers last week.
